docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This documentation is a step-by-step guide for setting up Visual Studio Code as an integrated development environment for collaborative projects. Tailored specifically for macOS users, it explains how to access shared repositories on GitHub to collaborate with other developers, and also how to configure third-party extensions and keyboard shortcuts to facilitate program writing and enhance productivity.

Visual Studio Code is an integrated development environment (IDE) designed by Microsoft for developers to write, edit and debug code. It supports a wide range of programming languages, including JavaScript, Java, Python, and more.

docs.title: Intended Users
docs.text:
This guide is targeted specifically towards the following users:

  • Beginner developers without software development experience
  • Intermediate developers with software development experience but have never used Visual Studio Code

docs.title: Required Knowledge
docs.text:
The documentation assumes the following:

  • Working knowledge of Git and GitHub — you should have an understanding of the purpose and functionality of Git and GitHub

Please note that, this documentation only provides instructions for setting up Visual Studio Code as an integrated development environment for your projects. It does not cover any knowledge related to programming languages.

docs.title: Prerequisite Requirements
docs.text:
Before starting, please ensure you have the following:

  • a computer running macOS
  • Visual Studio Code v1.98+ installed
  • Git v2.39+ installed
  • a GitHub account

docs.title: Content Overview
docs.text:
By reading this documentation, you will learn to:

  • Configure GitHub repositories
  • Set up third-party extensions
  • Customize keyboard shortcuts

docs.text:

docs.text:

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
This section outlines the technical terms that have been used throughout the documentation. The following technical terms are arranged in alphabetical order:

Terms Explanations Commit A snapshot of your repository at a specific time which records your progress. Commit message A message which explains the corresponding commit. Directory A file system structure that organizes and stores files and other directories, also known as a folder. Disable (extensions) Temporarily turning off an extension without uninstalling it, preventing it from running until re-enabled. Enable (extensions) Activating a previously disabled extension to restore its functionality. Extension A small add-ons package that enhances the functionality of software by adding new features or integrations. Extensions Marketplace A built-in platform in Visual Studio Code where users can browse, install, and manage extensions. Hotkey A combination of keys which will trigger a specific actions faster than using a mouse or other input devices. Integrated development environment A software application that provides comprehensive facilities for software development. Keybinding The assignment of an action to a specific keyboard shortcut, typically to enhance the speed and efficiency of performing that action. Key conflict A situation where multiple actions are assigned to the same keyboard shortcuts, resulting in malfunctions.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
This section identifies and diagnoses technical issues that may prevent the application from functioning properly. Below are some common problems you might have encountered:

Issues Possible Causes Solutions Unable to clone a GitHub repository to a local directory GitHyb repository URL is incorrect or not properly formatted. Double-check the repository URL. Ensure it ends with .git. "Repository Already Exists" or "Directory Not Empty" errors The destination directory in your local computer contains conflicting files. Clear the destination directory before cloning the repository. Unable to push commits to GitHub Your GitHub account is not configured properly in VS Code. Ensure your GitHub credentials are correctly set up in VS Code. If not, click on [View] → [Command Palette], and then select [GitHub: Sign in to GitHub] to reconfigure your GitHub account in VS Code. You do not have the write access to the remote repository. Check with the repository owner to confirm your access rights. Extensions not working There are corrupted installation, conflicting extensions, outdated version, or system issues. Disable and re-enable the extension, check for updates, and restart the application. Keyboard shortcuts not working Multiple actions are assigned to the same key combination. Resolve the key conflicts as instructed in Customized Keyboard Shortcuts. Unable to remove a keybinding There are bugs or technical issues with the keybinding configuration. Go to [File] → [Preferences] → [Keyboard Shortcuts] → [Open Keyboard Shortcuts (JSON)] to manually remove the keybinding from the keybindings.json file.

docs.title: Set up Third-party Extensions
docs.text: Extensions in Visual Studio Code are add-ons that enhance functionality by providing support for additional languages, debugging tools, themes, and integrations with external services. The Extensions Marketplace is a built-in platform where users can explore and manage these extensions to customize their development environment.

docs.title: Install a Third-Party Extension
docs.text:
1. Click [View] → [Extension] to open the Extensions Marketplace.

Tip

Two other ways to access the VS Code Extensions Marketplace are by:

i. Keyboard Shortcut: Press ⇧ ⌘ X on your keyboard

ii. Activity Bar: Click the [Extensions] icon (with four squares as shown in the above image) on the activity bar.

  1. Type the name of the extension you wish to install into the searchbar.

  2. Select an extension to open its information page.

  3. Click the [Install] button under the extension name. Once the [Install] button changes to [Uninstall], the extension has been successfully installed.

Tip

When the installation completes, the newly installed extension will be enabled by default.

docs.title: Disable, Enable and Uninstall an Extension
docs.text:
1. Select [View] → [Extension] to open the Extensions Marketplace.

  2. Click [Installed] to expand the dropdown menu, then select the installed extension to view its information page.

  3. Select the [Disable], [Enable] or [Uninstall] button on the information page.

  4. If you are disabling an extension, you must click [Restart Extensions] after clicking on the [Disable] button to apply the change.

docs.title: Modify Extension Settings
docs.text:
Tip

Modifying the extension settings may provide you a more personalized experience that suits your work habits.

  1. Follow the above section to open the Installed dropdown menu.

  2. Right-click the extension whose settings you wish to modify.

  3. Select [Settings] to open the setting tab for that extension.

  4. Change the settings as needed to tailor to your preference.

Success

Hurrah! You can now manage your own extensions in VS Code to personalize your development environment and enhance your productivity.

docs.title: Configure GitHub Repositories
docs.text:
Visual Studio Code provides a development environment which allows developers to share and collaborate on code with ease. This guide outlines the steps to configure an existing GitHub repository on your local computer, setting up a seamless working environment for remote collaboration on your projects.

Important

Before configuring a GitHub repository on your local computer, make sure your GitHub account is linked to VS Code and that you have the GitHub repository URL ready.

docs.title: Clone a GitHub Repository to Local Computer
docs.text:
1. Click [Clone Git Repository] on the Welcome tab.

Tip

By launching VS Code, you will land on the Welcome tab unless you have opened a project. If you are directed to an existing project, close it by clicking [File] → [Close Folder] to return to the Welcome tab.

  1. Enter or paste the GitHub repository URL into the searchbar.

  2. Select [Clone from URL] from the dropdown menu.

  3. Choose a local direcotory, i.e. a destination folder, to save the remote repository to.

  4. Click [Select as Repository Destination] button to begin the cloning process.

  5. Once the cloning is done, a pop-up window will appear. Click [Open] to open the downloaded repository in VS Code.

docs.title: Push to a GitHub Repository from Local Computer
docs.text:
Warning

Pushing to a GitHub repository makes your commits visible to anyone with access to the shared repository. Once pushed, your commits cannot be withdrawn or undone.

  1. Click [View] → [Source Control] to open the Source Control panel.

  2. Enter your commit message into the textbox.

  3. Click [✔ Commit] to commit your edits.

    </figure

  4. When ready, click [⋯] → [Push] on the Source Control panel to push your changes to the remote GitHub repository. The [⋯] button appears only when you hover over the Source Control panel.

    5. Success

    Congratulations! You can now begin collaborating with other developers in VS Code by cloning a GitHub repository to and pushing your progress from your local computer.

docs.title: Customize Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Visual Studio Code provides the flexibility of customizing keyboard shortcuts, allowing you to tailor the hotkeys to your preferences. By default, VS Code bundles pre-defined shortcuts for common actions when installed. This instruction guides you through the process of customizing the keybinding, helping you optimize your user experience and enhance productivity.

docs.title: Customize a Keyboard Shortcut
docs.text:
1. Click [Code] → [Settings] → [Keyboard Shortcuts] to open the Keyboard Shortcuts tab.

  2. Type the action you would like to customize into the searchbar (e.g. "Save", "Open File", etc).

  3. Right-click on the action you wish to modify.

  4. Select one of the following options:

    • [Change Keybinding] — to modify the current hotkey; or
    • [Add Keybinding] — to assign a new hotkey; or
    • [Remove Keybinding] — to remove the existing hotkey.

  5. Enter your desired key combination for the selected action if your are adding or changing keybinding, then press [Enter] to confirm.

docs.title: Resolve a Key Conflict
docs.text:
Important

Changing keyboard shortcuts may sometimes causes key conflicts where more than one action is assigned to the same key combination. If your keyboard shortcuts are malfunctioning, following this section to solve the issue.

  1. Select [Code] → [Settings] → [Keyboard Shortcuts] to open the Keyboard Shortcuts tab.

  2. Type the action that is malfunctioning into the searchbar.

  3. Right-click the malfunctioning action to open a menu.

  4. Click [Show Same Keybindings] to generate a list of all actions binded to the same hotkey.

  5. Review the list to ensure your chosen hotkey is not already in use by other action. If there is a key conflict, follow the steps from the above section to remove or change the conflicting keybinding.

Success

Cheers! You have successfully learned how to set up hotkeys in VS Code to save your time and boost up your productivity.
